metadata.notes: The text is fragmentary (X indicates damaged/missing signs). "i" likely refers to "i3" (oil), and "ukim" may be a variant of a temple or shrine designation, though the context is unclear due to the missing elements.

This follows the standard Ur III administrative formula for sealed documents. "kišib" (kicib) means "seal" or "sealed tablet," and "Ur-nigar" is a personal name. The phrase indicates that this document was sealed/authorized by Ur-nigar, a common attestation formula in Ur III period administrative texts.
"kin" means "work" and "-bi" is the possessive suffix "its". "sar" is a unit of area measurement. This is a typical administrative notation recording the area of work completed.

The term "u" typically refers to workdays in Ur III administrative texts. "Sag-nigura" appears to be a location name, likely referring to a storehouse or administrative building. The compound "sag-nig2-gur11-ra" can mean "storehouse" or "treasury" in Sumerian administrative contexts.

predictions.reference: year : “ The silver-chair of Enlil was fashioned . ”
predictions.prediction: year: "The golden throne of Enlil was fashioned."

metadata.translation: year: "The golden throne of Enlil was fashioned."
metadata.notes: This is a year name formula (mu = year). "ku" represents gold (kug), "guza" is throne/seat, "enlila" is the genitive form of the god Enlil, and "badim" (ba-dim2) indicates fashioning or making. Year names commemorating the creation of divine furniture, especially for major deities like Enlil, were common in Ur III administrative texts.

predictions.reference: booked out of ( the account of ) Ahuni ,

metadata.notes: Standard Ur III administrative formula. "ki" indicates source/origin ("from"), "Ahuni" is a personal name (with ablative suffix -ta), and "bazi" means "received/took out" (common verb in economic texts for disbursements or receipts).

The term "u4" typically means "day" or refers to a time marker. "muš-bi-an" can be interpreted as "at midnight" or "in the night," referring to a nocturnal time period. This phrase likely serves as a temporal marker in an administrative text.

Standard Ur III administrative formula. "ki" indicates source/origin ("from"), and "Budu" is a personal name. The ablative marker "-ta" confirms the meaning "from." This follows the common pattern seen in examples like "ki abasagata" (from Abbasaga) and "ki amarcubata" (from Amar-šuba).

This is the name of the legendary king of Uruk, the protagonist of the Epic of Gilgamesh, one of the earliest works of literature. The name appears in Sumerian as "Bilgamesh" or "Gilgamesh" and means roughly "the ancestor is a hero/young man."

tug = garment/textile; šagadu (cagadu) is a type of garment; sumun = old/used. This appears to be an administrative inventory entry listing old textiles.

Šara-zida is a personal name meaning "righteous Šara" (the deity). The pattern follows typical Ur III administrative texts where a number precedes a personal name, likely indicating a quantity of goods allocated to this person.
The text contains only "X" which represents an illegible or damaged portion of the original cuneiform tablet. This is a standard notation in Sumerian transliteration for unreadable signs.

This is a personal name followed by a profession. "akala" is a Sumerian personal name (A-kala), and "ašgab" (acgab) is the Sumerian term for leather worker or leatherworker. This follows the common Ur III administrative pattern of listing individuals by name and profession.

"la" could be a negation or part of a verbal form meaning "not" or "without." The complete phrase may refer to a fire that was not kindled or lit, possibly in a ritual or administrative context.

giri = "via" or "conveyed by" (indicates the intermediary or agent); cuecdar = personal name Šu-Eštar; sagi = cup-bearer (a palace official). This is a standard Ur III administrative formula indicating the person responsible for conveying goods.

Alternatively, it could be parsed as a phrase "the man of the temple of Nanna" but in administrative contexts, this pattern typically represents a personal name.

The term "še-lu" (celu) refers to barley-malt used in brewing, and "gaz" means broken/crushed. This is likely an administrative record of processed malt for beer production, common in Ur III period texts.

The text contains: "tir" (forest/grove), "balatimdurun" (a personal name or place name, possibly meaning "life-of-Durūn"), and "idab" which likely refers to "i-dab5" (granary/storehouse). The text describes the location of a property or field belonging to Lugal-musa situated opposite a vineyard.
"igi" means "before/in front of" or "witnessed by" in legal contexts; "dumu" means "son"; "ursuen" is a personal name (Ur-Suen/Ur-Sin), common in Ur III period texts

The text appears to be recording the dimensions of something (possibly a field, canal, or structure) with length, width, and depth measurements.

predictions.reference: year after : “ The house Puzris-Dagan was erected . ”

metadata.notes: This is an Ur III period year name formula. "mu us2-sa" indicates "the year following," referring to the year after a named event. "e" (house/temple) + personal/place name "Puzriš-Dagan" + "ba-du3" (was built) follows standard year name patterns. Puzriš-Dagan (modern Drehem) was an important administrative center during the Ur III period.

The term "cenumun" (še-numun) is a compound of "še" (barley/grain) and "numun" (seed). This is a common term in Ur III administrative texts referring to seed grain used for planting. See example 51 where "cenumun" appears in the phrase "NUMB cenumun aca erin" translated as "NUMB (gur) barley seed, fields of the work-troops."

This follows the pattern seen in examples like "NUMB nigtukuinabdu" → "NUMB ( mana wool for ) Nigtuku-inabdu" and "NUMB ninama" → "NUMB ( mana wool for ) Nin-ama". Lu-Enkidu is a common Sumerian personal name meaning "man of Enkidu".

Standard Ur III period patronymic formula. "u" = "and"; "lugalbaba" = personal name "Lugal-baba"; "dumu" = "son (of)"; "urlamma" = personal name "Ur-lamma". This pattern is commonly found in administrative texts listing individuals with their filiation.

metadata.notes: This is a standard Ur III administrative formula for recording weights of silver. "mana" = mina (unit of weight), "gin" = shekel (1/60 of a mina), "ku" is abbreviated from "kubabbar" meaning silver. Compare with example 71 which shows the full form "kubabbar".

cunigin = šunigin "total/grand total"; gamun = "cumin" (a spice). This follows the standard Ur III administrative pattern for commodity totals, similar to Example 56 "cunigin NUMB gur" = "total : NUMB"

This is a personal name meaning "Šulgi is my helper" or "Šulgi-the-helper". Šulgi was a famous king of the Ur III dynasty, and names incorporating his name were common during this period. The element "ḫazir" relates to assistance or helping.
The term "uc" (úš) means "to die/death" in Sumerian. "Lu-Šara" is a personal name meaning "Man of Šara" (Šara being a deity). This appears to be a death record, common in Ur III administrative texts.

cunigin = "total" (šunigin); NUMB = number placeholder; sila = sila3 (volume measure); mun = salt; gur = gur (unit of capacity, approximately 300 liters). This is a typical Ur III administrative summary formula.
